name: 2-(2-pyridyl)-3H-indol-3-one N-oxide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4276

name: 2-(2-pyridyl)-3H-indol-3-one N-oxide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4276
Reason:
The compound 2-(2-pyridyl)-3H-indol-3-one N-oxide has various structural features affecting its melting point. The basic unit we will consider is benzene, known to have a melting point around 5.5°C. The structural features we will account for are: 

- Indole ring: +60 (the presence of a fused ring system like the indole usually raises the boiling point due to increased molecular complexity and size)
- Pyridine ring: +50 (adding a heterocyclic aromatic ring such as pyridine with a nitrogen atom contributes to the rigidity and the possibility of forming hydrogen bonds)
- Carbonyl group (C=O): +40 (the carbonyl group can form additional intermolecular forces through dipole interactions)
- N-oxide group: +20 (provides additional polarity and potential for hydrogen bonding, increasing the melting point)

Adding these modifications together, we estimate a shift in the melting point as follows.
Prediction: The predicted melting point of 2-(2-pyridyl)-3H-indol-3-one N-oxide is 5.5 (benzene base) + 60 (indole ring) + 50 (pyridine ring) + 40 (carbonyl group) + 20 (N-oxide group) = 175.5°C. Considering the uncertainties in evaluating the contribution of each group, the predicted value is close to the actual value of 182°C.
